audio_caption: The audio clip begins with heavy metal music, featuring a driving rhythm and a dark, intense mood, likely created by electric guitars. Transitioning to speech, a male voice starts by welcoming the listener to an event, referencing "Apocalypse Orchestra" from Sweden. This is followed by an inquiry about the band's current status. The speech is interspersed with the continuing presence of heavy metal music, suggesting an interview or introduction occurring within a music venue or performance space.

The audio clip starts with two speakers, both male, beginning an interview, describing that they are doing very well. One mentions that it's been busy since their album release around 18 months ago, and 2018 was all about gigs. The other adds that they're going back to the studio to write new material, noting this was a rare appearance on stage this year. One speaker mentions longing to write new material, looking forward to getting back into the studio.

The clip opens with a male interviewer asking about the possibility of upcoming work from the interviewee, whom he says is "in hibernation at the moment." A male interviewee responds in a casual tone, expressing uncertainty and a "pessimistic guess" that it may not be until 2020. Another male interviewee elaborates in a conversational manner, discussing the band's perfectionism and desire to surpass their first album, implying the process may be slow but steady due to the complexity of their songs. The clip ends with the interviewer saying "Okay".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about the band's future musical direction. Another male voice responds, mentioning making music with "more variation." He elaborates on how the band feels that they've had more to do with their music. He mentions differences in tempo and adding weird instruments to the mix. A third male voice confirms adding more medieval sounds. The second voice adds that he can play just about anything. The first male adds some laughter. Then he talks about the amount of stories to tell about the weird people and ideas in medieval times. He adds that there are no shortages of stories. Another male agrees, and adds "beautiful art, artwork and lots of inspiring things." Then, the second male says that there is a lot of material to choose from. The first speaker says okay, and then asks where their interest in this topic came from. In the background there are ambient sounds suggesting they are in a populated indoor environment.

The audio clip begins with a question posed by a male speaker, showing interest "with the music of the olden days for 11th century music." Another male voice provides an answer, expressing that for him it started with a group called "Garmarna." He heard them when he was 18 and was "totally hooked." They were "playing like folk rock versions of Swedish medieval ballads," and he notes that "that was the thing that started it for me". The speaker mentions that Garmarna includes a hurdy-gurdy, inspiring the speaker to buy one, followed by another voice saying "yeah". This second male speaker explains that he and Michael have known each other for a long time and have played folk music together in bands, some of which were folk rock bands. He continues, "since a previous band went into hibernation" then joking "Oh, this sounds menacing." That band went to the side and Michael had the idea of "bringing it from rock up to metal," slowing tempos down, "doing a lot of older melodies." He emphasizes that he has listened to medieval and early music since he was a teenager so he "was hooked on the idea right away." The first male speaker then speaks up again, mentioning "folk metal has been around for some time now."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker asking a question about incorporating old folk melodies with modern metal. The speaker sounds inquisitive. A second male speaker responds, saying it's a lot of interpretation because it's difficult to know exactly how music sounded hundreds of years ago, elaborating on difficulties with transcription and that it's not wrong to do anything with it. The speaker seems to be talking in a contemplative tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker rejecting something, then elaborating on different kinds of folk metal, describing the ordinary type as "dancing and drinking beer and quite jolly music," mentioning polka and the accordion favorably. He contrasts this with a preference for darker, more medieval routes. Another male speaker interjects, mentioning the Swedish melancholy but acknowledging that they're happy guys. There's background noise throughout, characterized by consistent, general ambient sounds.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing music. He believes "a melody and an arrangement of music in symbiosis can bring out the best of both parties." Folk music back in the day, he says, involved melodies, drums, dance and storytelling. He characterizes the speaker's music as an "ultra-modern interpretation" of folk music mixing.

The clip opens with a male speaker expressing his love for crossover elements in food, culture, and music, saying he "almost can't imagine playing in a band where you don't mix two genres." He suggests it would be "insane" to play just metal. Another male voice in the background agrees, mentioning strange instruments. The first speaker then transitions to discussing tales and inspiration. Throughout the clip, there's a constant, low-level background noise that sounds like a restaurant or dining hall, punctuated by indistinct chatter and clattering sounds.

The clip starts with a male voice, speaking in a casual, inquisitive tone, suggesting that the speaker mentioned old Swedish tales. Another male voice responds, starting by noting how the Norwegian have their Edda and where inspiration comes from, acknowledging the Edda's older Viking Age origins and labeling it more modern from around the 11th century, and that there are lots of stories from there. Light music plays in the background, giving off an adventurous mood. Background sounds also include general ambient noise that sounds like a market.

The audio clip begins with speech, with one male speaker discussing the band's common theme: the plague, specifically the Black Death. He mentions inspiration derived from stories in books, emphasizing a fondness for "weird stuff," such as the flagellant movement and the plague doctor with his "fearful mask." The speaker humorously adds, "Bring out your dead," then states that they like "the strange stuff." The dialogue unfolds against the backdrop of consistent ambient restaurant noise, with intermittent clatter suggesting an active dining environment.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Swedish history, describing it as "war-ridden." Another male voice acknowledges and the first speaker continues, explaining that they draw inspiration from it. The speaker emphasizes that they try to "avoid this glory of battle stuff," because they believe that being on the battlefield was "very horrifying." The second male voice concurs, stating that very few people actually experience the glory of war. He says most people going to war "had no choice to be there," because of circumstance such as being "forced, they owed money," or they were "slaves." He continues to say they were "harsh times to begin with." The speaker states they "want to..."

The clip starts with two male speakers discussing the challenge of historical accuracy when sources are scarce, but they aim for an authentic take on lyrical themes, trying to imagine what life was like back then. Their collective feeling is that it was not very nice, and they want to bring that feeling to the listener as well. They agree it was harsh and that Sweden was very war-ridden. One speaker mentions that they’ve been around the world doing bad stuff and don’t condone that. Their tone is conversational and thoughtful.

The audio clip features a conversation between two speakers, one male and the other likely male as well. One speaker asks about plans for the year, specifically mentioning "Studio 10." The other responds, saying there may be "a few live surprises yet to be announced," but that they "will be few this year." He expresses some sadness about the limited number of surprises.

The clip features two male speakers discussing their love for being on stage and past experiences touring Europe and Scandinavia, emphasizing their desire to create more music, even if only for themselves. The speakers sound enthusiastic and passionate about their work. The background ambiance includes some music, along with sounds of speech which suggest the environment is a social space.

The clip begins with background noise as a male speaker notes that the audience loves it, asking "what makes a gig good for you guys?". Another male speaker emphasizes the audience's reaction, stating "if you said it's good then we're then we are happy", emphasizing their enjoyment of the audience singing along to the lyrics. The second speaker continues that they "always want to bring something extra to our shows," as they don't have the opportunity to tour as often, and want to "bring it all" when they travel long distances. The speaker also explains that they "have some extra performers or some other surprises," as this is important for them and the crowd, "so it's good to see that they actually they actually like our efforts." The first speaker agrees saying "that is that we're".

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the band's approach of planning each gig separately and having "lots of ideas for future gigs as well," speaking in a casual, conversational tone.  Another male responds with appreciation, calling their approach "commitment," followed by expressions of gratitude and well wishes from both speakers. The audio is punctuated by indistinct sounds in the background.
